captions.text:
When you touch an object and it feels warm
or cold, what is that really telling you about

the object? Here, I have a metal hard drive
and a book and I'm going to ask people to

compare their temperatures. Which one do you
think will feel warmer - the book or the hard
drive?
The temperatures?

Yeah, tell me if one is hotter or colder or
if they're the same temperature. How do they
feel?
This is slightly cooler than this one.
Oh, that's warmer.
Yeah, agreed.

I'd say the hard drive is a lot colder than
the book. 'Cause the book's got more knowledge.
Why do you think that is?

Metal's normally a little bit chillier if
you leave it in a colder temperature.

What if I said they're both the same temperature?
What would you say?
I'd tell you you're lying.
I'd think you were lying, yeah.

Well, maybe the way I can prove it is I have
an infrared thermometer. What do you think
we're going to see?

I think science might be able to answer that.
And I'm not a scientist!
Make a prediction for me.
I still think that's colder.
Would you bet me money?
I don't have any cash.

Let's measure the temperature of the book.
What do you see?
OK. Now measure the temperature of that.
19.0. Alright, well, now I believe you.

I'm trying to figure it out, actually. Trying
to figure out why'd they be the same temperature.
They don't feel the same temperature, though.

So, why does that feel colder if they're the
same?
Good one. You know the answer?
I'm coming to you guys for answers.
We're creatives, not intellectuals.
Well, create an answer for me!
I'm not a scientist! Come on, you tell me.

I'll try to answer that question with another
little experiment. Here is an aluminium block.
Ooh! Nice and cold.

And a plastic block. How do their temperatures
compare?
Completely different.
Aluminium's going to be much colder.
Yeah?
This actually feels colder.

Let's take this to the next level. I'll put
an ice cube on both plates. What will we see?

I'm guessing it would stay solid on this one
and melt on this one.

So it's going to melt on the plastic but stay
solid on the aluminium?
Yes, but maybe I'm wrong.

That one will melt more quickly than on the
aluminium.
You'd think so.
Yeah, 'cause it's cold.
I think they're the same.

We put an ice cube on each of those. What
do you see?
It's melting quicker on the aluminium.
My God, it's melting!

This is melting quicker than that one, even
though this is aluminium and that's plastic.
So which one felt colder?
This one.
How does that make sense?
No idea.
Could aluminium be bad for the environment?
How would aluminium be bad for the environment?
It's thawing the ice quicker, isn't it?
You want the answer?
Yes, please!

It's about thermoconductivity - the rate at
which heat is transferred from one object

to another. So when you felt these blocks
originally, I know this one felt a lot colder.

But you know from the other example we did,
that they must both be the same temperature.
True.

They've both been outside for a while. We
see the aluminium block is melting the ice

faster than the plastic block because it's
conducting the heat to the ice cube faster.

With the plastic block, it's a worse thermoconductor.
So, heat is being transferred less quickly
to this ice block and so it's staying iced.
OK. I believe you.
Make sense?
Yes. Definitely.

In our first example, the hard drive felt
colder, even though it was at the same temperature

as the book. That's because the aluminium
conducts heat away from your hand faster than
the book conducts heat away from your hand.
Sure. That seems logical.

Which makes the hard drive feel colder and
the book feel warmer. So when you touch something,

you don't actually feel temperature. You feel
the rate at which heat is conducted, either

towards or away from you. Think about this
next time you hop out of the shower in winter.

It's much nicer to stand on the bath mat than
on a towel beside it. Not because the bath

mat is warmer but because it conducts heat
less quickly away from you.

comments.author: Saulo Rocha

comments.text:
"When you touch something you don't actually feel its temperature, you feel 
the rate at which heat is conducted either towards or away from you." But 
temperature IS the rate at which the object's atoms are moving, so you 
really are feeling its temperature, no? So MAYBE when you are touching the 
aluminum and the book cover, though both at the same room temperature, you 
feel the the aluminum colder because, being a good heat conductor, the 
aluminum receives/drags the energy of our body faster.﻿
comments.author: Saulo Rocha

comments.text:
+Saulo Rocha No, the temperature is not also the rate of heat transfer. The 
temperature is only the mean kinetic energy of the object's molecules.
You CAN feel the rate of heat transfer. And that is what you feel when you 
touch something.
comments.author: likewhatijustsaid

comments.text:
+likewhatijustsaid I was just pointing a contradiction in Derek's 
explanation: "When you touch something you don't actually feel its 
temperature, you feel the rate at which heat is conducted either towards or 
away from you." Ok, right, you can't feel the temperature, but neither can 
you feel the rate of heat transfer, because that is also temperature.
comments.author: Saulo Rocha

comments.text:
Yes, temperature is "the rate at which the object's atoms are moving", but 
that's not what you feel when you touch something. When you touch 
something, what you feel is the CHANGE in temperature between your hand and 
the object, not the temperature itself.

comments.author: Warren Brooks

comments.text:
I think most people can easily recall that Aluminum is a conductor and 
plastic is an insulator but few people remember clearly what that means in 
terms of heat transfer exchange of surroundings and objects.  For instance 
- the example of hard drive v. book on your hand took energy from your body 
and conducted it to the air through the Aluminum better than the book.  But 
in the other example, Aluminum conducted the energy from the air to the ice 
better than the plastic did.  Considering a phase change also occurred in 
the ice example, there were many subtle nuances in the two examples that 
could mix up even an educated citizen.﻿

comments.text:
I'm going to momentarily interrupt the usual squabble of YouTube's comment 
section to ask a question. Ok so what about black things? why do they seem 
hotter than other things even if they're pretty much the same material? do 
all black things just transfer heat faster or what?﻿
comments.author: [ireton]

comments.text:
Black surfaces are good at absorbing radiation, which can make them heat up 
comparatively faster. For example, if you were to leave a black car and a 
white car in the sunlight, the black one will heat up quicker since it'll 
absorb more radiation, whilst the white one will reflect most of it off. 
However, black surfaces are also the best at emitting radiation as well, so 
if you were to out both cars back in the shade, the black one will cool 
down faster.

comments.text:
Note that the trick with the IR probe is just that, a trick. When we touch 
something we learn how cold it makes our skin.

If he had measured the temperature of the spot on the book where there had

comments.author: jbiasutti

comments.text:
Its all about the surface, if you notice the longer that people held the 
book the more likely they were to be certain the book was warmer. If you 
notice the presenter was very careful to measure the other side of the book 
to that being held. I also expect a trick photography as well as the book 
and the aluminium have different emissivity, so there is no way the IR 
thermometer would read the same for both if they were at the same 
temperature.
comments.author: jbiasutti

comments.text:
+Jeffery Wells
If it was warmer, less heat would be transferred to it.
Aluminum has a higher thermal capacity than the paper, so a certain ammount 
of heat will cause a smaller change in temperature.
But the more important point is that you can't actually say what the 
temperature of the aluminum is, since it will have a temperature gradient 
with a different value at each point.
comments.author: radialwellendichtrin

comments.text:
Actually the aluminum would almost certainly be warmer, since more heat was 
transferred to it.
comments.author: Jeffery Wells

comments.text:
+radialwellendichtrin yeah... heat conductivity. He explained that in the 
video. The assumption about temperature is still wrong.
comments.author: Skidonti

comments.text:
Yes! Exactly this. Assuming that the book is isothermic after being held is 
a very erroneous. And the fact of the matter is that the people's fist 
assumption about the aluminum being colder is correct. The hand and the 
aluminum/paper meet at a contact temperature, which is highly dependent on 
the material properties. Aluminum will be able to 'drag' the hand's 
temperature down much further than the book.

comments.text:
I think most of you are stupid and confuse knowledge with intelligence. ;-) 
Not having knowledge isn't being stupid, but not wanting knowledge is

Derek is also "wrong", we DO sense temperature, not the rate of energy 
transfer from our body. But we sense the temperature around our receptors 
in the skin (or other locations). If you touch a material with good 
conductivity and its colder than 37 degrees C, energy (heat=vibrations on 
atomic/molecular level) will transfer from your skin and it will get 
colder.﻿

comments.author: curt murtha

comments.text:
So, is it important for the elderly living in a cold climate to keep the 
heat in or to keep the cold out?
Of course, science tells us that cold is not a thing - It's a simple 
absence of heat and that therefore, the thing to do it to keep in the heat.
This was the basis of many failed government interventions trying to get 
people to insulate their homes.
For the elderly of a certain generation, cold can be a palpable enemy. 
Changing the message from government to say that insulation will keep out 
the cold massively improved take up of home insulation.
The moral? Science uses precise language but it's a mistake to think that 
just because people don't understand the specifics of that language that 
they don't grasp the concepts - I doubt that any of these people would 
choose an aluminium house over a plastic house.﻿
comments.author: baldieman64

comments.text:

easily. What is it about the aluminum being a good conductor that makes it 
feel cold? What's the difference between heat and temperature? Was heat 
mentioned?﻿

comments.author: Bryan Klein

comments.text:
+Jeffery Wells
Absolutely. Well said. Time and again in my own life I have found myself 
confused about "simple" questions, whilst "knowing" underlying facts and 
principles perfectly well - certainly well enough to pass basic exams.
comments.author: mwtosh

comments.text:
There's a huge difference between knowing a fact about something (like most 
metals conduct heat faster than most plastics) and fully realizing the 
implications. Derek could have asked a series of questions that would have 
led them right into the correct answer, but that doesn't demonstrate the 
gap in understanding that he was pointing out.
